Module Contents

utils.clean_document(text)

Clean and normalize the document by lowercasing and removing special characters.

This function processes the input text by converting it to lowercase and removing any non-alphabetical characters (such as numbers, punctuation, or special symbols), leaving only lowercase alphabetic characters and spaces. It helps normalize the text for further processing like shingling or hashing.

Parameters:

text (str) – The input document text to be cleaned.

Returns:

A cleaned version of the input text, containing only lowercase letters and spaces.

Return type:

str

Example

>>> clean_document("Hello, World!123")
'hello world'
utils.shingle(text, k=5)

Generate k-shingles (or k-grams) from a given text.

A shingle is a contiguous sequence of k words. This function splits the cleaned text into words and generates all possible k-shingles from those words. Shingling helps capture local word context for use in similarity detection and MinHashing.

Parameters:

  • text (str) – The input document text that has been pre-processed.

  • k (int) – The number of words in each shingle. Default is 5.

Returns:

A set of k-shingles, where each shingle is a string of k words joined by spaces.

Return type:

set

Example

>>> shingle("this is an example of a document", k=3)
{'this is an', 'is an example', 'an example of', 'example of a', 'of a document'}
utils.minhash(shingles, num_hashes=100)

Generate a MinHash signature for the given set of shingles.

MinHash is used to estimate the Jaccard similarity between two sets efficiently. This function computes a MinHash signature for a given set of shingles by generating num_hashes hash functions and returning the minimum hash value for each function.

Parameters:

  • shingles (set) – A set of k-shingles (strings) representing the document.

  • num_hashes (int) – The number of hash functions to use in generating the MinHash signature. Default is 100.

Returns:

A MinHash signature represented as a list of num_hashes integers, where each entry is the minimum

hash value for that hash function over the shingles.

Return type:

list

Example

>>> shingles = {"this is an example", "example of a document", "a document example"}
>>> minhash(shingles, num_hashes=3)
[210933193411394158751014314048262142248, 7042737232409725043981610333941128952, 113933543564394106622393219348875832082]
class utils.UnionFind

Union-Find (Disjoint Set) data structure with path compression for efficient merging and finding.

Union-Find (also known as Disjoint Set) is a data structure that efficiently handles merging of sets and finding the root or representative element of a set. It uses path compression to flatten the tree structure, improving the efficiency of future find operations.

parent

A dictionary mapping each element to its parent element. If an element is its own parent, it is the root of its set.

Type:

dict

find(x)

Finds the root of the set containing element x, with path compression to improve efficiency.

union(x, y)

Merges the sets containing elements x and y.

parent

Initializes an empty Union-Find structure.

find(x)

Find the root of the set containing element x with path compression.

Path compression is used to make future queries faster by setting each element’s parent directly to the root. If the element x is not yet in the Union-Find structure, it is initialized as its own root.

Parameters:

x – The element whose set root is being queried.

Returns:

The root element of the set containing x.

Example

>>> uf = UnionFind()
>>> uf.union(1, 2)
>>> uf.find(1)
2
union(x, y)

Union the sets containing elements x and y.

This method merges the sets that contain elements x and y. If the elements are already in the same set, no change is made. Otherwise, one set’s root is updated to point to the other set’s root.

Parameters:

  • x – The first element to union.

  • y – The second element to union.

Example

>>> uf = UnionFind()
>>> uf.union(1, 2)
>>> uf.union(2, 3)
>>> uf.find(3)
2
utils.read_tsv(tsv)

Read a TSV (tab-separated values) file and return a dictionary of its contents.

This function reads a TSV file where each line consists of an index and a text value separated by a tab. The index is used as the key, and the text as the value in the returned dictionary.

Parameters:

tsv (str) – The file path to the TSV file.

Returns:

A dictionary where keys are the integer indices from the TSV file, and values are the text content.

Return type:

dict

Example

>>> read_tsv('documents.tsv')
{1: 'This is the first document.', 2: 'Another document with different content.'}
utils.split_dict(input_dict, num_splits)

Splits a dictionary into a specified number of smaller dictionaries.

Parameters:

  • input_dict (dict) – The input dictionary to be split.

  • num_splits (int) – The number of splits.

Returns:

A list of dictionaries with split entries.

Return type:

list

utils.majority_vote(candidate_sets)

This function performs a majority vote on a list of sets of candidate pairs.

Parameters:

candidate_sets (list of sets) – List of sets containing candidate pairs.

Returns:

The pairs that appear in the majority of sets.

Return type:

list
